notes.name: EU Free Trade Agreements Awaiting Ratification
notes.title: EU Free Trade Agreements Awaiting Ratification

vignettes.title: United Kingdom : Is an Export Licence Required?

updates.update_title: The UK Withdraws from the EU
updates.update_content:
The UK left the EU on 31 January 2020. According to the "Notice to exporters 2020/03: exporting and trading items subject to strategic controls during the transition period" published by the Export Control Joint Unit on 29 January 2020, current UK export licensing arrangements will continue to apply until the end of the transition period on 31 December 2020.

For more information, please see the following link:

https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/notice-to-exporters-202003-exporting-and-trading-items-subject-to-strategic-controls-during-the-transition-period

updates.update_title: The UK Withdraws from the EU
updates.update_content:
The UK left the EU on 31 January 2020. According to the "Notice to exporters 2020/03: exporting and trading items subject to strategic controls during the transition period" published by the Export Control Joint Unit on 29 January 2020, current UKexport licensing arrangements will continue to apply until the end of the transition period on 31 December 2020.

For more information, please see the following link:

https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/notice-to-exporters-202003-exporting-and-trading-items-subject-to-strategic-controls-during-the-transition-period

updates.update_title: The UK Withdraws from the EU
updates.update_content:
The UK left the EU on 31 January 2020. According to the "Notice to exporters 2020/03: exporting and trading items subject to strategic controls during the transition period" published by the Export Control Joint Unit on 29 January 2020, current UKexport licensing arrangements will continue to apply until the end of the transition period on 31 December 2020.

For more information, please see the following link:

https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/notice-to-exporters-202003-exporting-and-trading-items-subject-to-strategic-controls-during-the-transition-period

updates.update_title: The EU Renews Its Terrorist List of Persons and Organisations Subject to Sanctions
updates.update_content:
On 13 January 2020, the European Council renewed the "EU terrorist list," which sets out persons, groups, and entities subject to restrictive measures with a view to combatting terrorism. Persons, groups, and entities on the list are subject to the freezing of their funds and other financial assets in the EU. It is also prohibited for EU operators to make funds and economic resources available to these persons, groups, and entities.

The Council is empowered to establish an EU list and impose related restrictive measures under Council Common Position 2001/931/CFSP and Council Regulation (EC) No 2580/2001.

The list can be found here.

updates.update_title: The EU Extends Sanctions Against Russian Individuals and Entities
updates.update_content:
The EU Permanent Representatives Committee (COREPER) has decided to extend sanctions against individuals and entities designated under Council Regulation (EU) 269/2014 and Council Decision 2014/145/CFSP who are said to be responsible for undermining or threatening the territorial integrity or sovereignty of Ukraine.

On 12 September 2019, the EU Council approved the extension of sanctions over actions against the territorial integrity of Ukraine with Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2019/1403.

More information is available in the press release here.

updates.update_title: The EU Council Extends Sanctions Against Russia
updates.update_content:
The EU Council has extended sanctions against Russian individuals and entities said to be “undermining the territorial integrity of Ukraine” for one year, until 23 June 2020. The measures relate to Crimea and Sevastopol, and include prohibitions on:

  • Imports of ​products, investment, and provision of tourism services
  • Exports of goods, technology, and services relating to oil, gas, and mineral sectors

EU leaders also agreed to prolong sectoral sanctions against Russia for six months due to the lack of implementation of the Minsk Agreements, the peace accord for eastern Ukraine. These measures target Russia’s financial, energy, and defence industries, and will be renewed on 31 July 2019.

updates.update_title: The UK Publishes Legislation to Transfer EU Sanctions Law to the UK Sanctions Regime for Guinea and Burundi
updates.update_content:
The UK has published legislation to transfer its sanctions on Burundi and the Republic of Guinea, which implement EU sanctions, into standalone UK sanctions regimes upon Brexit. The purpose of this change is to ensure that the UK is able to operate its own sanctions regimes in relation to the two countries after it leaves the EU.

The UK has also published new guidance pages on the sanctions, which are available here for Guinea and here for Burundi.

updates.update_title: The ECJU Amends Export Control Order 2008 and Updates Control List
updates.update_content:
The Export Control Joint Unit (ECJU) has amended the Export Control Order 2008. Changes have been made to:


  • Main order Article 2(1) (interpretation)
    •  
  • Article 36 (offences relating to prohibitions and restrictions in the torture regulation)

  • Schedule 2 (military goods, software, and technology)
    •  
  • Schedule 4 (countries and destinations subject to stricter export or trade controls)


The new order, The Export Control (Amendment) Order 2019 (SI 2019 No. 989), comes into force on 30 June 2019. In particular, the order implements Commission Directive (EU) 2019/514, making changes to the list of defence-related products corresponding to changes made to the European Common Military List that was previously updated following changes agreed in the Wassenaar Arrangement. See details of wider changes provided below.

The ECJU also updated the "Consolidated list of strategic military and dual-use items that require export authorisation." It can be found here.

updates.update_title: The UK Passes the Sanctions (Amendment) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019
updates.update_content:
The UK has passed the Sanctions (Amendment) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019, which make amendments to a number of EU sanctions regimes to ensure (inter alia) that they continue to apply within the UK after Brexit. The regulations will come into force on exit day.

The text of the amendments can be found here.

updates.update_title: The EU Renews Ukraine Sanctions Until September 2019
updates.update_content:
In March 2019, the EU extended the validity of Ukraine-related restrictive measures for a further six months, until 15 September 2019. The EU also added eight Russian officials to the list of those subject to restrictive measures in respect of actions undermining or threatening the territorial integrity, sovereignty, and independence of Ukraine.

The measures now apply to a total of 170 persons and 44 entities. They consist of a travel ban and an asset freeze. EU operators are also forbidden from making funds available to the listed individuals and entities.

The full text can be found here.

updates.update_title: The UK Publishes Cyberattack Sanctions Regulations
updates.update_content:
The UK has published the Cyber-Attacks (Asset-Freezing) Regulations 2019, which will come into force on 11 June 2019, to transpose the new EU sanctions regime into UK law targeting those responsible for cyberattacks on EU member states, third states, or international organisations.

These measures comprise asset-freezing measures on persons or entities and prohibitions against dealing with the funds of designated persons. The regulations create UK offences where the prohibitions are contravened and provide for penalties. 

More information can be found here.

updates.update_title: The EU Imposes a Cyberattack Sanctions Regime
updates.update_content:
On 17 May 2019, the European Council established a framework that allows the EU to impose targeted restrictive measures to deter and respond to cyberattacks that constitute an external threat to the EU or EU member states, including cyberattacks against third states or international organisations where restricted measures are considered necessary to achieve the objectives of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP).

Cyberattacks falling within the scope of the new sanctions regime are those that have significant impact and:

  • Originate or are carried out from outside the EU,
  • Use infrastructure outside the EU,
  • Are carried out by persons or entities established or operating outside the EU, or
  • Are carried out with the support of persons or entities operating outside the EU.

Attempted cyberattacks with potentially significant effects are also covered by this sanctions regime.

The Council Regulation can be found here.

updates.update_title: The EU Commission Compares EU and UK Approaches to Sanctions Policy Post-Brexit
updates.update_content:
The European Commission has published slides comparing the EU and UK positions on framework for the future EU/UK relationship on foreign, security, and defence policy.

The EU approach is to pursue a sanctions policy “driven by the EU27 foreign objectives,” consulting and exchanging information with international partners, including the UK, to facilitate early information sharing, minimise the risk of divergence, and eventually enable the UK’s convergence with EU sanctions policy. EU/UK consultation is to be:

  • Reciprocal – Information presented in advance about envisaged new sanctions or reviews
  • Scalable – Regular sanctions dialogue (e.g., on overall policy and practice, current regimes and their effectiveness, and exchange of good practices) and intensified/in-depth dialogue at certain key stages (e.g., deciding on whether to impose, lift, or renew sanctions)
  • Formalised – Parameters to be included in the consultation mechanism on foreign policy

The UK approach is to “develop sanctions together with the EU,” achieving an “EU-UK equal footing on sanctions policy” to exchange information on listings and their justification. There will be UK/EU sanctions dialogue, including “intensive interaction” during the adoption process of sanctions.

updates.update_title: The EU Adds Two People to Its ISIL/Daesh and Al-Qaeda Sanctions List
updates.update_content:
On 18 June 2018, the UN Security Council added two Filipino nationals to its ISIL/Daesh and Al-Qaeda sanctions list.

As a result, both individuals are subject to asset freezes, travel bans, and a prohibition to supply/sell them arms and related material. The UN press release is here.

On 21 June 2018, the EU implemented both of those UN listings by adopting Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/888.

An OFSI notice is here.

updates.update_title: The EU Extends Its Crimea Sanctions
updates.update_content:
On 19 June 2018, the EU extended its sanctions in response to the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol by Russia for one year, until 23 June 2019.

These sanctions, which apply to EU persons and EU-based companies, are limited to the territory of Crimea and Sevastopol, and include:

1)  An import ban into the EU on goods from Crimea and Sevastopol;

2)  Restrictions on EU trade and investment related to certain economic sectors and infrastructure projects in Crimea and Sevastopol;

3)  A prohibition to supply tourism services in Crimea or Sevastopol; and

4)  An export ban for certain goods and technologies to Crimean companies or for use in Crimea in the transport, telecommunications, and energy sectors and related to the prospection, exploration, and production of oil, gas, and mineral resources. Technical assistance, brokering, construction, or engineering services related to infrastructure in these sectors must not be provided either.

An EU press release is available here. ?For more information, see Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/880.

An Export Control Joint Unit notice is available here.

updates.update_title: The EU Implements the UN's Human Smuggling Sanctions
updates.update_content:
In June 2018, the UN Security Council added six individuals to its Libya sanctions list for their involvement in the “illicit trafficking of migrants in Libya.” The six individuals are Ermias Ghermay, Fitiwi Abdelrazak, Ahmad Oumar al-Dabbashi, Mus’ab Abu-Qarin, Mohammed Kachlaf, and Abd Al-Rahan al-Milad.

These individuals are now subject to asset freezes and travel bans.

This is the “first time that the UN has imposed sanctions against human traffickers.”

On 14 June 2018, the EU announced that it transposed the UN sanctions into EU law. See Council Implementing Decision (CFSP) 2018/872 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/870.

updates.update_title: The EU Updates Its Blocking Regulation
updates.update_content:
On 6 June 2018, the European Commission amended its Blocking Regulation to protect EU companies from the extraterritorial effects of the U.S.'s Iran sanctions, which were reimposed after its withdrawal from the JCPOA.

The amended version of the Blocking Regulation (see the regulation here and the annex here) was originally published as Council Regulation (EC) No 2271/96 of 22 November 1996 and the External Lending Mandate (ELM) by the European Investment Bank (EIB).

An explanatory memorandum notes that “some of the measures which the United States will reactivate against Iran have extra-territorial effects and… violate international law and impede the attainment of the Union’s objectives.” The EU will therefore amend the regulation that previously related to the U.S.’s Cuba and Libya measures to include Iran. The update to the EIB’s ELM would make Iran eligible for investment activities by the EIB.

If there are no objections to the amendments, the updated Blocking Regulation will enter into force at the beginning of August 2018.

updates.update_title: The EU Updates Its Iran Nonproliferation Sanctions
updates.update_content:
On 6 June 2018, the EU updated a number of entries appearing on its Iran sanctions list in relation to the nonproliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMDs).

Although the EU lifted all of its Iran nuclear sanctions under the JCPOA, these nonproliferation-related measures remained in place.

See Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/833 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/827.

An OFSI notice is available here.

updates.update_title: The EU Extends Its Syria Sanctions
updates.update_content:
On 28 May 2018, the EU extended its sanctions against Syria until 1 June 2019, in view of the “continuing repression of the civilian population of Syria.”

The sanctions were also updated to remove two deceased individuals.

See Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/774, Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/778, and the EU statement here.

updates.update_title: The EU Launches a Process to Activate the Iran Blocking Statute
updates.update_content:
Following President Donald Trump’s decision to withdraw the United States from the JCPOA and reimpose sanctions on Iran, the European Commission announced that it has “acted on four fronts” to mitigate the “impact of US sanctions on European businesses” and to “maintain the growth of trade and economic relations between the EU and Iran.”

These four fronts are:

  1. It has launched the formal process to activate the Blocking Statute by updating the list of U.S. sanctions on Iran falling within its scope. The Blocking Statute “forbids EU companies from complying with the extraterritorial effects of US sanctions, allows companies to recover damages arising from such sanctions from the person causing them, and nullifies the effect in the EU of any foreign court judgements based on them.” The aim is for the blocking measure to come into force before 6 August 2018 (the date on which the first tranche of U.S. sanctions take effect).
  2. It has launched the process for removing obstacles for the European Investment Bank to decide under the EU budget guarantee to finance activities outside the EU in Iran.
  3. As “confidence building measures,” the Commission will “continue and strengthen the ongoing sectoral cooperation with, and assistance to, Iran, including in the energy sector and with regard to small and medium-sized companies.”
  4. The Commission will encourage member states to explore the possibility of one-off bank transfers to the Central Bank of Iran. (“This approach could help the Iranian authorities to receive their oil-related revenues, particularly in case of US sanctions which could target EU entities active in oil transactions with Iran.”)

The EU Parliament and Council will have two months in which to object to the first two measures above, once proposed, before they enter into force.

A press release is available here.

updates.update_title: The EU Adds Five People to Its Ukraine Sanctions
updates.update_content:
On 14 May 2018, the EU added five people to its targeted sanctions on those said to be responsible for undermining the territorial integrity of Ukraine (asset freezes and travel bans).

These people were included for being involved in the “organisation of the Russian presidential elections of 18 March 2018 in the illegally annexed Crimea and Sevastopol, thereby actively supporting and implementing policies that undermine the territorial integrity, sovereignty and independence of Ukraine.” They were also said to “hold positions of responsibility in the electoral commissions of Crimea or Sevastopol.”

For more information, see the EU press release, Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/706, and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/705.

updates.update_title: The EU Extends Its Burma (Myanmar) Arms Embargo
updates.update_content:
On 26 April 2018, the EU extended its arms embargo on Burma (Myanmar) for one year and expanded it to include:

1.      A prohibition on the export of dual-use goods for use by the military and border guard police

2.      Restrictions on the export of equipment for monitoring communications that might be used for internal repression

3.      A prohibition on the provision of military training to and military cooperation with the Burma (Myanmar) army

The EU also adopted a legal framework to impose targeted sanctions (travel bans and asset freezes) against individuals of the Myanmar Armed Forces (Tatmadaw) and the border guard police who are deemed responsible for (inter alia) “serious human rights violations.”

For more information, see Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/655 and Council Regulation (EU) 2018/647.

An EU press release is available here.

updates.update_title: Updated UK Guidance on Doing Business with Iran
updates.update_content: Following President Donald Trump’s decision to withdraw the United States from the JCPOA and reimpose sanctions on Iran, the UK has updated its guidance for British companies doing business in Iran.

updates.update_title: The Sanctions and Anti-Money Laundering Act Receives Royal Assent
updates.update_content:
On 24 May 2018, Her Majesty The Queen gave Royal Assent to the Sanctions and Anti-Money Laundering Act. This means the piece of legislation has completed its passage through Parliament and is now an act rather than a bill.

A copy of the act is here, and all the documents and drafts leading up to its passage are available here.

updates.update_title: The UK Aligns with UN Sanctions on North Korea
updates.update_content:
The UK has passed secondary legislation on North Korea, bringing into full effect UNSC resolution 2397, passed on 22 December 2017, which targets fuel imports and places a ban on the export of food, machinery, electrical equipment, earth and stones, wood, and vessels from the DPRK, and on the import of industrial equipment, machinery, transportation vehicles, and industrial metals.

The North Korea (United Nations Sanctions) (Amendment) Order 2018 (SI 2018/523) and the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (Sanctions) (Overseas Territories) (Amendment) Order 2018 (SI 2018/524) will come into force on 22 May 2018.

updates.update_title: The U.S. Withdraws from the JCPOA
updates.update_content:
On 8 May 2018, U.S. President Donald Trump announced that the United States will withdraw from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) and begin reimposing U.S. nuclear-related sanctions on the Iranian regime. 

The other signatories to the JCPOA – the United Kingdom, France, Germany, China, Russia, and the European Union – continue to support the nuclear agreement and have expressed willingness to keep enforcing its provisions in all respects. 

On 9 May, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) certified that, "as of today," Iran had met all of the requirements of the nuclear deal.

Remember, training your employees on these regulations and how they apply to your company and products is crucial to ensuring continued compliance with the law.

updates.update_title: The EU Extends Iran Human Rights Sanctions
updates.update_content:
The Council of the EU has extended existing sanctions against Iran for one year due to concerns over serious human rights violations.

The sanctions currently comprise travel bans and asset freezes against a total of 82 people and one entity, as well as a ban on exports to Iran of equipment that might be used for internal repression or for monitoring telecommunications. First put in place in 2011, these measures are now set to expire on 13 April 2019.

For further information, see the press notice here.

updates.update_title: The EU Adds Individuals to Autonomous North Korea Sanctions
updates.update_content:
The EU has added four individuals to its North Korea sanctions list for their involvement in “deceptive financial practices which are suspected of contributing to the DPRK’s nuclear-related, ballistic-missile-related or other weapons of mass destruction-related programmes.”

Asset freezes were imposed against these individuals under the EU's autonomous sanctions measures against North Korea.

For more information, see Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/611 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/602.

An EU press release is available here.

An implementing notice by the UK’s Office of Financial Sanctions Implementation is available here.

updates.update_title: The UN Imposes New North Korea Sanctions
updates.update_content:
On 30 March 2018, the United Nations Security Council imposed additional sanctions on North Korea.

These added 21 shipping companies, 27 ships, and one individual to the list of individuals and entities subject to the measures imposed by paragraphs 8(d) and 8(e) of UNSC resolution 1718 (2006) adopted under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations.

For the list of designated entities, see: https://www.un.org/press/en/2018/sc13272.doc.htm.

The EU has implemented these measures by adopting Council Implementing Decision (CFSP) 2018/551 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/548.

updates.update_title: The EU Implements New UN Sanctions on Somalia
updates.update_content:
The EU has adopted Council Implementing Decision (CFSP) 2018/417 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/413, by which it implements a previous UNSC measure that added two people to its Somalia and Eritrea sanctions list.

The individuals, Ahmad Iman Ali and Abdifatah Abubakar Abdi, are sanctioned for their alleged links with Al-Shabaab, the African branch of Al-Qaeda.

updates.update_title: The EU Sanctions Four Syrians Over Chemical Weapons Role
updates.update_content:
The EU has added four people to its Syria sanctions list for alleged involvement in the development and use of chemical weapons against the people of Syria.

The individuals include a high-ranking military official and three scientists working at the Scientific Studies and Research Centre (SSRC), the government entity responsible for developing and producing non-conventional weapons, including chemical weapons, and the missiles to deliver them. The SSRC itself has been under EU sanctions since 2011.

An EU press release announcing the measures is available here.

updates.update_title: The EU Implements UN Central African Republic Sanctions
updates.update_content: Implementing UN resolution 2399 (2018), on 13 March 2018, the EU adopted Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/391 and Council Regulation (EU) 2018/387, which, among other things, amended the exemptions to the arms embargo and the designation criteria under its Central African Republic (CAR) sanctions regime.

updates.update_title: The EU Extends Its Russia Territorial Sanctions
updates.update_content:
The EU has extended its sanctions on Russia for “actions undermining or threatening the territorial integrity, sovereignty and independence of Ukraine” for a further six months. These measures, consisting of asset freezes and travels restrictions on 150 people and 38 entities, will continue to apply until 15 September 2018.

For more informaton, see Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/392 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/388.

The EU press release announcing the decision is available here.

updates.update_title: The EU Implements UN ISIL/Daesh and Al-Qaeda Listings
updates.update_content:
On 8 March 2018, the EU implemented the recent decision of the UN Security Council to add two individuals, Salim Mustafa Muhammad Al-Mansur and Umar Mahmud Irhayyim Al-Kubaysi, and one entity, Al-Kawthar Money Exchange, to its ISIL/Daesh and Al-Qaeda sanctions list. The named parties are now subject to asset freezes.

For more information, see Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/349 and the OFSI notice here.

updates.update_title: The EU Extends Ukraine Sanctions
updates.update_content:
On 5 March 2018, the EU extended the asset freezes against 13 individuals “responsible for the misappropriation of Ukrainian state funds or for the abuse of office causing a loss to Ukrainian public funds” until 6 March 2019.

Two people were also removed from the list: Olena Leonidivna Lukash and Serhii Petrovych Kliuiev.

For more information, see Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/333 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/326.

An EU press release is available here, and an OFSI notice is here.

updates.update_title: The EU Sanctions Two Syrian Individuals
updates.update_content:
On 26 February 2018, the EU imposed travel bans and asset freezes against two ministers of the Syrian government “for being responsible for the violent repression against the civilian population in Syria, benefiting from or supporting the regime, and/or being associated with such persons.”

The individuals are Mohamed Mazen Ali Yousef, Minister of Industry, and Imad Abdullah Sara, Minister of Information.

See Council Implementing Decision (CFSP) 2018/284 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/282.

Those legal acts also update the information relating to five previously sanctioned individuals.

An EU press release is available here, and an OFSI notice is available here.

updates.update_title: Further EU Sanctions Against North Korea
updates.update_content:
On 26 February 2018, the EU increased its sanctions against North Korea in order to align itself with UN Security Council resolution 2397 (2017). As a result, the following measures were transposed through the adoption of Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/293 and Council Regulation (EU) 2018/285:

(i) A cap on the export of all refined petroleum products to North Korea, from 2 million barrels to 500,000 barrels per year

(ii) A ban on imports from North Korea of food and agricultural products, machinery, electrical equipment, earth and stone, and wood

(iii) A ban on exports to North Korea of all industrial machinery, transportation vehicles, and expansion to all iron, steel, and other metals

(iv) Further maritime restrictive measures against vessels where there are reasonable grounds to believe that they have been involved in the breach of UN sanctions

(v) A requirement to repatriate all North Korean workers abroad within 24 months

Under UNSC resolution 2397, the prohibition on the export of crude oil had already been introduced in the EU on 16 October 2017, and the 16 individuals and one entity were sanctioned on 8 January 2018. On 22 January 2018, the EU also imposed unilateral sanctions against a further 17 individuals.

For more information, read the EU's press release here.

updates.update_title: The EU Renews Sanctions on Belarus
updates.update_content:
The EU has extended its sanctions against Belarus for one year, until 28 February 2019.

The restrictions impose an arms embargo and targeted asset freezes and travel bans against four people. Additionally, the EU has also prolonged a derogation allowing the export of biathlon equipment to Belarus, such as sporting rifles, subject to prior authorisation.

See Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/280 and Council Regulation (EU) 2018/275. An EU press release is available here.

updates.update_title: The EU Extends Zimbabwe Sanctions
updates.update_content:
The EU has extended its sanctions on Zimbabwe until 20 February 2019. 

Under these measures, EU travel restrictions and asset freezes will continue to be imposed on seven people: Robert Mugabe, Grace Mugabe, Happyton Bonyongwe, Augustine Chihuri, Constantine Chiwenga, Perence Shiri, and Phillip Sibando, as well as one entity, Zimbabwe Defence Industries. However, those sanctions are currently suspended, except in relation to Robert Mugabe, Grace Mugabe, and Zimbabwe Defence Industries. 

For more information, see Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/224. An OFSI notice confirming these changes is available here.

updates.update_title: The EU Implements the UN's DRC Sanctions
updates.update_content:
The EU added four people to its Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) sanctions list under Council Implementing Decision (CFSP) 2018/202 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/197.

The individuals are Muhindo Akili Mundos, Gédéon Kyungu Mutanga Wa Bafunkwa Kanonga, Guidon Shimiray Mwissa, and Lucien Nzambamwita. 

The measures implement sanctions previously imposed against these people by the UN Security Council. 

An OFSI notice is available here.

updates.update_title: The EU Adds Unilateral South Sudan Sanctions
updates.update_content:
The EU added three people to its South Sudan sanctions list under Council Implementing Decision (CFSP) 2018/168 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/164. 

The individuals were named as Paul Malong, Michael Makuei Leuth, and Malek Reuben Riak. 

This is the first time that the EU has imposed targeted measures under its South Sudan sanctions regime in addition to those sanctioned by the UN Security Council.

An OFSI notice regarding these sanctions is here.

updates.update_title: The EU Renews Its Tunisia Sanctions
updates.update_content:
The EU has renewed the listings of all persons and entities under its Tunisia sanctions list until 31 January 2019.

The designations are made under Annex to Council Decision 2011/72/CFSP, as amended by Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/141, and in Annex I to Council Regulation (EU) 101/2011, as implemented by Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/137.

The EU notice explains that those affected may submit a request to the EU Council for a reconsideration of the decision before 31 October 2018.

updates.update_title: The EU Sanctions Venezuelan Officials
updates.update_content:
The EU has added seven officials to its Venezuela sanctions list under Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/90 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/88.

The targets include the head of the Venezuelan judiciary, Maikel José Moreno Pérez, and other officials who have allegedly been involved in the “non-respect of democratic principles or the rule of law as well as in the violation of human rights.” 

The measures impose targeted asset freezes and travel bans against the designated parties.

An EU press release and an OFSI notice confirming the designations are available.

updates.update_title: The EU Renews Libya Ship Listings
updates.update_content:
The EU has renewed and amended the listings of two vessels under its Libya sanctions list until 17 April 2018 and 28 April 2018, respectively. The former regards a vessel named "Capricorn" (since 10 February 2018, this has been renamed "Nadine"), while the latter concerns "Lynn S."

The restrictions prohibit certain vessels from loading, transporting, or discharging crude oil from Libya and accessing EU ports. 

The regulations were made under Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/126 and Council Implementing Decision (CFSP) 2018/132, and Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/166 and Council Implementing Decision CFSP) 2018/167, implementing Council Decision (CFSP) 2015/1333. 

The decisions reflect previous UN Security Council resolutions implementing these changes.

updates.update_title: The EU Adds 17 People to Its North Korea Sanctions List
updates.update_content:
Under Council Decision (CFSP) 2018/89 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/87, the EU added 17 people to its North Korea sanctions list, including a number of North Korean embassy diplomats.

The designations were made because of their alleged involvement in “illegal trade activities” and activities aimed at “facilitating the evasion of [UN] sanctions.” 

An EU press release and an OFSI notice confirming these changes are available.

updates.update_title: The EU Implements New UN Sanctions Against North Korea
updates.update_content:
Implementing UN Security Council resolution 2397 (2017), the EU added 16 individuals and one entity to its North Korea sanctions list. The entity was named as North Korea's Ministry of People’s Armed Forces (MPAF). 

Asset freezes and travel restrictions apply against these parties under Council Implementing Decision (CFSP) 2018/16 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/12.

For more information, read the relevant EU notice.

Further, in line with paragraph 6 of UNSC resolution 2375, the EU has also added four vessels to its North Korea sanctions list under Council Implementing Decision (CFSP) 2018/58 and Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/53. The vessels are: Billions No. 18, Ul Ji Bong 6, Rung Ra 2, and Rye Song Gang 1.

An OFSI notice is available here.

updates.update_title: The EU Amends Al-Aqsa Listing
updates.update_content:
The EU has published a notice amending the terrorist asset-freeze listing of Al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigade in light of new information. 

For the EU terrorism list, see the Annex to Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2017/1420.

updates.update_title: The EU Updates Its ISIL/Daesh and Al-Qaeda Sanctions List
updates.update_content:
The EU has updated its ISIL/Daesh and Al-Qaeda sanctions list in line with the latest UN Security Council changes, which removed one person, Zayn Al-Abidin Muhammad Hussein, and amended the entry of another, Seifallah Ben Hassine. 

For more information, see Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/50.

The UK has implemented these sanctions. For further information, see the OFSI notice.

updates.update_title: The UK Imposes Unilateral Russia Sanctions Following Nerve Agent Attack
updates.update_content:
On 15 March 2018, Prime Minister Theresa May presented a statement to the House of Commons on the UK government’s response to the nerve agent attack against a former Russian spy and his daughter in London earlier that month.

Among other measures, she announced:

- New legislative powers will be developed to “harden [the UK’s] defences against all forms of hostile state activity,” including the addition of a targeted power to detain those suspected of hostile state activity at the UK border (a power that is currently only permitted in relation to those suspected of terrorism)

- The UK government will table an amendment to the UK Sanctions Bill, “to strengthen our powers to impose sanctions in response to the violation of human rights”

- Increased checks on private flights, customs, and freight coming from Russia

- Russian-state assets will be frozen wherever there is evidence that “they may be used to threaten the life or property of UK nationals or residents” 

- UK efforts to seek a “robust international response” before the UN Security Council

- UK suspension of high-level diplomatic contact with Russia

updates.update_title: Greater Money-Laundering Risk in Sanctions Jurisdictions
updates.update_content:
HM Treasury has identified a number of jurisdictions with “strategic deficiencies” in their anti-money-laundering and counterterrorist financing regimes. It advised firms to consider a number of measures in accordance with the risks. 

Of the 11 listed jurisdictions, six are currently subject to UN, EU, or U.S. sanctions: North Korea, Iran, Iraq, Syria, Tunisia, and Yemen. The others were Ethiopia, Serbia, Sri Lanka, Trinidad and Tobago, and Vanuatu. 

An advisory notice explaining the memorandum is available here.

updates.update_title: New OFSI Sanctions Blog
updates.update_content:
The Office of Financial Sanctions Implementation (OFSI) has launched a blog that helps to ensure that financial sanctions are properly understood, implemented, and enforced in the UK.

It is available here.

updates.update_title: The UK Passes the Export Control (North Korea Sanctions) Order 2018
updates.update_content: As of 14 March 2018, the UK's Export Control (North Korea Sanctions) Order 2018, SI 2018/200, which makes provision for the EU trade restrictions against North Korea, as contained in Council Regulation (EU) 2017/1509 (as amended), is in effect.

updates.update_title: Sanctions Breaches Reported in the UK in 2017
updates.update_content:
Responding to a written question in Parliament, the UK government stated that 133 suspected sanctions breaches were reported to OFSI in 2017, with an approximate value of £1.4 billion.

As of April 2017, 103 breaches had been reported since OFSI gained the ability to impose monetary penalties under the Policing and Crime Act 2017. 

Further information is available here.

updates.update_title: The UK Passes the Export Control (Venezuela Sanctions) Order 2018
updates.update_content:
The UK has passed the Export Control (Venezuela Sanctions) Order 2018, SI 2018/108, providing for the enforcement of EU sanctions against Venezuela – as contained in Council Regulation (EU) 2017/2063. The sanctions measures include an arms embargo under a framework to impose targeted measures against those responsible for human rights violations and/or undermining democracy and the rule of law in Venezuela. The order came into force on 26 February 2018.

The UK has also passed the Venezuela (Sanctions) (Overseas Territories) Order 2018, SI 2018/179, which gives effect in specified overseas territories of the aforementioned regulations. This came into force on 8 March 2018.

The overseas territories to which this order extends are Anguilla; the British Antarctic Territory; the British Indian Ocean Territory; the Cayman Islands; the Falkland Islands; Montserrat; Pitcairn, Henderson, Ducie, and Oeno Islands; St Helena, Ascension, and Tristan da Cunha; South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands; the Sovereign Base Areas of Akrotiri and Dhekelia (Cyprus); the Turks and Caicos Islands; and the British Virgin Islands.

updates.update_title: OFSI Renews Certain Terrorist Designations
updates.update_content:
The Office of Financial Sanctions Implementation (OFSI) has renewed the terrorist listings for Euzkadi Ta Askatasuna, the Hizballah Military Wing, and four senior Hamas officials under the Terrorist Asset-Freezing etc. Act 2010 (TAFA).

Further information is available here.

updates.update_title: UK Human Rights Sanctions in Force
updates.update_content:
The UK government has passed the Criminal Finances Act 2017 (Commencement No. 4) Regulations 2018 (SI 2018/78), which, among other things, brought section 13 of the Criminal Finances Act 2017 into force as of 31 January 2018. 

Specifically, under Part 5 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002, the definition of "unlawful conduct” was expanded to include conduct (occurring outside of the UK) that “constitutes, or is connected with, the commission of a gross human rights abuse or violation.” These provisions are also known as "Magnitsky-style" sanctions.

Guidance for the implementation of these measures has been made available by the UK government here.

updates.update_title: The UK Adds Two New Russian Terrorism Designations
updates.update_content:
On 22 January 2018, the Office of Financial Sanctions Implementation (OFSI) designated two people pursuant to section 4 of the Anti-Terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001.

The sanctions concern Andrey Lugovoy, listed as a “Member of the Russian Duma (Parliament),” and Dmitri Kovtun, a Moscow-born national listed as the “General Director of Global Project.” Under the new desgnations, it is now a crime to make funds available to these individuals.

For more information, consult the OFSI notice.

updates.update_title: The EU Sanctions the Governor of Sevastopol
updates.update_content:
The EU has added Dmitry Vladimirovich Ovsyannikov, Governor of Sevastopol, to its Ukraine sanctions list for actions “undermining Ukraine’s territorial integrity.”

For more information, see Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2017/2153 and Council Decision (CFSP) 2017/2163.

updates.update_title: The UN Extends Arms Embargoes on Eritrea and Somalia
updates.update_content:
On 14 November 2017, the UN Security Council adopted resolution 2385 (2017), extending the modified arms embargo on Somalia and the authorisation for maritime interdiction of illicit arms imports and charcoal exports until 15 November 2018. The arms ban on Eritrea has also been renewed until 15 November 2018.

A UN press release is available here.

updates.update_title: The EU Removes FARC from Its Terrorism Sanctions
updates.update_content:
In September 2016, following the signing of the Colombia peace agreement between Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) and the Colombian government, the EU suspended its terrorism sanctions.

On 13 November 2017, the EU removed FARC from its terrorism sanctions listings.

For further information, see Council Regulation (EU) 2017/2061, Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2017/2064, Council Decision (CFSP) 2017/2072, and Council Decision (CFSP) 2017/2073.

updates.update_title: The EU Implements Enhanced North Korea Measures
updates.update_content:
In October 2017, the EU expanded its ban on EU investment in and with North Korea to all economic sectors and decreased personnel remittances that can be sent to North Korea from EUR 15,000 to EUR 5,000.

These measures have now been published in a new regulation to ensure that they are uniformly applied across the EU.

The regulation (Council Regulation (EU) 2017/2062) also includes a new list of luxury goods subject to an import and export ban, after the Council invited the EU Commission to review the existing list in consultation with member states.

updates.update_title: The EU Imposes Targeted Sanctions and an Arms Embargo Against Venezuela
updates.update_content:
On 13 November 2017, the EU Council imposed an arms embargo on Venezuela, and introduced a legal framework for travel bans and asset freezes against those involved in human rights violations and non-respect for democracy or the rule of law.

In its conclusions on the situation in Venezuela, the Council stated that democratic institutions had been eroded by the establishment of “an all-powerful Constituent Assembly.” The Council says that the measures will be used “in a gradual and flexible manner” alongside its diplomatic and political efforts. It also said that the measure can be reversed if Venezuela makes progress on these issues, or, conversely, that they may be expanded if the situation worsens. 

The implementing instruments are Council Regulation (EU) 2017/2063 and Council Decision (CFSP) 2017/2074.

updates.update_title: The EU Renews Listing of Vessel Under Libya Sanctions
updates.update_content:
The EU has renewed and amended the listing of the vessel Lynn S under its Libya sanctions regime until 29 January 2018.

For further information, see Council Implementing Decision (CFSP) 2017/2008 and Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2017/2006.
